abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is characterized by cardiac enlargement and impaired ventricular contractility leading to heart failure. A single report identified variants in leiomodin-2 (<jats:italic>LMOD2</jats:italic>) as a cause of neonatally-lethal DCM. Here, we describe two siblings with DCM who died shortly after birth due to heart failure. Exome sequencing identified a homozygous <jats:italic>LMOD2</jats:italic> variant in both siblings, (GRCh38)chr7:g.123656237G > A; NM_207163.2:c.273 + 1G > A, ablating the donor 5′ splice-site of intron-1. Pre-mRNA splicing studies and western blot analysis on cDNA derived from proband cardiac tissue, MyoD-transduced proband skin fibroblasts and HEK293 cells transfected with <jats:italic>LMOD2</jats:italic> gene constructs established variant-associated absence of canonically spliced <jats:italic>LMOD2</jats:italic> mRNA and full-length LMOD2 protein. Immunostaining of proband heart tissue unveiled abnormally short actin-thin filaments. Our data are consistent with <jats:italic>LMOD2</jats:italic> c.273 + 1G > A abolishing/reducing <jats:italic>LMOD2</jats:italic> transcript expression by: (1) variant-associated perturbation in initiation of transcription due to ablation of the intron-1 donor; and/or (2) degradation of aberrant <jats:italic>LMOD2</jats:italic> transcripts (resulting from use of alternative transcription start-sites or cryptic splice-sites) by nonsense-mediated decay. <jats:italic>LMOD2</jats:italic> expression is critical for life and the absence of LMOD2 is associated with thin filament shortening and severe cardiac contractile dysfunction. This study describes the first splice-site variant in <jats:italic>LMOD2</jats:italic> and confirms the role of <jats:italic>LMOD2</jats:italic> variants in DCM.</jats:p>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: STC is director of Frontier Genomics Pty Ltd (Australia). STC receives no financial payments for her director role. Frontier Genomics Pty Ltd (Australia) has no existing financial relationships that will benefit from publication of these data. The remaining co-authors do not have any relationships, financial or otherwise, that may result in a perceived conflict of interest.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: Ethical approval was obtained from the Human Research Ethics Committees of the Children’s Hospital at Westmead, Australia (2019/ETH11736). Informed, written consent was obtained from all study participants or their guardians. Control heart tissue from a non-failing heart (NF14, 14-month old infant) was obtained from the Sydney Heart Bank (University of Sydney, Australia, sample code 5.114) with approval from the Human Research Ethics Committee [CitationRef removed]. Heart tissue from LMOD2 knock-out (KO) mice described in [CitationRef removed] was obtained via animal procedures approved by The Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee at the University of Arizona.

title: Neonatal-lethal dilated cardiomyopathy due to a homozygous LMOD2 donor splice-site variant
